title: The mysterious science of pain - Joshua W. Pate

multiple-choice.question: In 1995, the British Medical Journal published a report about a 29-year-old builder who experienced agonizing pain after accidentally jumping onto a 15-centimeter nail. What was surprising about this incident?

options.label: A
options.text: The nail had pierced through his foot.

options.label: B
options.text: The nail had never touched his foot at all.

options.label: C
options.text: The builder was not wearing steel-toed boots.

options.label: D
options.text: The builder did not seek medical attention immediately.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the biological process that involves the nervous system's protective response to harmful or potentially harmful stimuli?
What happens when the brain receives electrical signals from nociceptive sensors?

options.label: B
options.text: It weighs the importance of the signals and produces pain if necessary.

options.label: C
options.text: It sends the signals back to the nerve endings.

multiple-choice.question: What can happen to nerve fibers if they are activated repeatedly?
What is the definition of chronic pain?

options.label: C
options.text: Pain that is severe and debilitating.

options.label: D
options.text: Pain that is mild and manageable.

multiple-choice.question: What can influence a person's experience of pain, according to research?
In one study, what was found to affect children's experience of pain?

options.label: C
options.text: Their beliefs about pain and control.

multiple-choice.question: What was found to affect volunteers' perception of pain in an experiment involving a cold rod and colored lights?
What is often the most effective approach to pain treatment, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A single-pronged approach involving only pain specialists.

options.label: B
options.text: A multi-pronged approach involving various healthcare professionals.

options.label: C
options.text: A pharmacological approach involving only medication.

options.label: D
options.text: A non-pharmacological approach involving only therapy.

multiple-choice.question: What have studies shown to have a huge role in influencing nociception, contrary to previous thinking?

title: Can a black hole be destroyed? - Fabio Pacucci

multiple-choice.question: What happens to an object that crosses the event horizon of a black hole?

options.label: A
options.text: It is immediately torn apart by the black hole's gravitational field.

options.label: B
options.text: It disappears and never re-emerges, adding to the black hole's mass and expanding its radius.

options.label: C
options.text: It is released back into the universe with increased energy.

options.label: D
options.text: It merges with the black hole to form a new celestial body.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the only way to potentially "destroy" a black hole?

options.label: A
options.text: By throwing another black hole at it.

options.label: B
options.text: By waiting for it to evaporate through Hawking radiation.

options.label: C
options.text: By releasing a massive amount of energy into the black hole.

options.label: D
options.text: By creating a wormhole to drain the black hole's energy.

multiple-choice.question: What is the basis for Hawking radiation, as proposed by Stephen Hawking in 1974?

options.label: B
options.text: Gravitational waves emitted by black holes.

options.label: C
options.text: The collision of virtual particle pairs.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to virtual particle pairs that appear at the edge of a black hole's event horizon?

options.label: A
options.text: They collide and annihilate each other.

options.label: B
options.text: One particle escapes the black hole's pull while the other falls in.

options.label: C
options.text: They merge to form a new particle.

options.label: D
options.text: They are absorbed by the black hole.

multiple-choice.question: According to black hole thermodynamics, what is the relationship between a black hole's mass and its temperature?

options.label: A
options.text: The more massive the black hole, the higher its temperature.

options.label: B
options.text: The more massive the black hole, the lower its temperature.

options.label: C
options.text: The mass of the black hole has no effect on its temperature.

options.label: D
options.text: The temperature of a black hole is constant regardless of its mass.

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated temperature of a black hole with the mass of the asteroid Vesta?
Why do most black holes not evaporate quickly through Hawking radiation?

options.label: C
options.text: Because they accrete matter and energy more quickly than they emit Hawking radiation.

options.label: D
options.text: Because Hawking radiation is not a real phenomenon.

multiple-choice.question: How long would it take for a black hole with the mass of our Sun to fully evaporate through Hawking radiation?
What happens to a black hole when it reaches a mass of around 230 metric tons?

options.label: C
options.text: It has only one more second to live before releasing all its energy.

options.label: D
options.text: It merges with another black hole.

multiple-choice.question: What do some scientists believe certain gamma-ray flashes detected in the sky might be evidence of?

options.label: A
options.text: The formation of new black holes.

options.label: C
options.text: The last moments of small, primordial black holes formed at the dawn of time.

title: Why should you read “Crime and Punishment”? - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: Who wrote the novel "Crime and Punishment"?
What is the name of the protagonist in "Crime and Punishment"?
In what year was "Crime and Punishment" first serialized in a literary magazine?
What motivates Raskolnikov to commit the murder in the novel?

options.label: D
options.text: Desperation due to poverty and a desire to continue his studies

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the city where the story of "Crime and Punishment" takes place?
What was Fyodor Dostoyevsky's occupation before becoming a writer?
Why was Dostoyevsky arrested and sentenced to death?

options.label: B
options.text: For participating in a radical intellectual circle

options.label: D
options.text: For speaking out against the government

multiple-choice.question: What is the title of Dostoyevsky's 1864 novella that explores similar themes to "Crime and Punishment"?
What philosophical doctrines does Raskolnikov use to rationalize his crime?
What is notable about the way Dostoyevsky reveals the central murder in the novel?

options.label: A
options.text: The details are slowly revealed throughout the story

options.label: B
options.text: The murder is not revealed until the end of the novel

options.label: C
options.text: The details of the murder are revealed in the first act

options.label: D
options.text: The murder is not explicitly described

title: How do self-driving cars “see”? - Sajan Saini

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary challenge for a self-driving car when navigating obstacles on the road?

options.label: B
options.text: Detecting and responding to hazards in real-time

multiple-choice.question: What technology is used in self-driving cars to detect and respond to obstacles on the road?
What is the main difference between radar and LIDAR technology?

options.label: A
options.text: Radar uses radio waves, while LIDAR uses infrared laser

options.label: B
options.text: Radar is more accurate than LIDAR

options.label: C
options.text: LIDAR is more expensive than radar

options.label: D
options.text: Radar is used for short-range detection, while LIDAR is used for long-range detection

multiple-choice.question: How does LIDAR technology determine the shape or depth of features on the road?

options.label: A
options.text: By firing a single laser pulse and measuring the time it takes to return

options.label: B
options.text: By firing a train of super-short laser pulses and measuring the time difference between returns

options.label: C
options.text: By using a combination of radar and camera sensors

options.label: D
options.text: By relying on pre-mapped data of the road

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of integrated photonics in LIDAR technology?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a pulse of light by switching a laser on and off

options.label: B
options.text: To periodically block the light reliably and rapidly using a Mach-Zehnder modulator

options.label: C
options.text: To amplify the signal of the LIDAR system

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce the size and cost of the LIDAR system

multiple-choice.question: What is the principle behind the Mach-Zehnder modulator?
What is the benefit of pairing a Mach-Zehnder modulator with a super-sensitive, fast-acting light detector?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased depth resolution to a few centimeters

options.label: B
options.text: Increased depth resolution to a millimeter

options.label: C
options.text: Reduced size and cost of the LIDAR system

multiple-choice.question: What is the limitation of the first generation of automobile LIDAR systems?

options.label: A
options.text: They rely on complex spinning assemblies that scan from rooftops or hoods

options.label: D
options.text: They are not compatible with integrated photonics

multiple-choice.question: What is the advantage of using integrated photonics to shrink modulators and detectors to a tiny size?

options.label: A
options.text: Reduced size and cost of the LIDAR system

options.label: C
options.text: Increased speed and reliability of the LIDAR system

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential benefit of using a steerable laser beam in LIDAR technology?

options.label: B
options.text: Reduced size and cost of the LIDAR system

options.label: C
options.text: Increased speed and reliability of the LIDAR system

options.label: D
options.text: Ability to probe and see more thoroughly than existing LIDAR systems

title: How this disease changes the shape of your cells - Amber M. Yates

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of red blood cells in the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: To transport nutrients from the digestive system to tissues

options.label: B
options.text: To transport oxygen from the lungs to tissues

options.label: C
options.text: To remove waste products from tissues

multiple-choice.question: What is the shape of a normal red blood cell?
What causes the deformation of red blood cells in sickle-cell disease?

options.label: B
options.text: A single genetic mutation altering the structure of hemoglobin

options.label: D
options.text: A lack of oxygen in the blood

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of sickled red blood cells accumulating in a vessel?

options.label: C
options.text: Blockage of the vessel, preventing oxygen from reaching tissues

multiple-choice.question: What is the average lifespan of a sickled red blood cell?
What is the condition characterized by a constantly depleted supply of red blood cells?
Why did the sickle-cell mutation originally evolve as a beneficial adaptation?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase oxygen delivery to tissues

options.label: B
options.text: To make red blood cells more resistant to malaria

options.label: C
options.text: To increase blood flow to tissues

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary location where malaria infections occur worldwide?
What is the name of the medication that was previously the only available treatment to reduce sickling and blunt symptoms?
What is a potential new approach to treating sickle-cell disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Editing DNA to enable stem cells to produce abnormal hemoglobin

options.label: B
options.text: Keeping oxygen bonded to hemoglobin to prevent sickling

options.label: C
options.text: Reducing the stickiness of healthy red blood cells

options.label: D
options.text: Editing DNA to enable stem cells to produce normal hemoglobin

title: "Accents" by Denice Frohman

multiple-choice.question: Who is the speaker of the poem "Accents"?
How does the speaker's mother hold her accent?
What type of language does the speaker's mother speak?

options.label: C
options.text: A mix of Spanish and English

options.label: D
options.text: A mix of French and German

multiple-choice.question: What happens when the speaker's mother says "ah ha"?

options.label: B
options.text: The sky in her mouth becomes a Hector Lavoe song

multiple-choice.question: Why can't the speaker's mother's tongue lay itself down flat enough for the English language?

options.label: C
options.text: Because it has too much rhythm and music

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker's mother's accent remind her of?
What is the effect of saying "wepa" to a stranger?
What is the speaker's mother's tongue compared to?
What is the significance of the coqui's of el campo in the poem?

options.label: A
options.text: They represent the speaker's love of music

options.label: B
options.text: They represent the speaker's mother's connection to her heritage

options.label: C
options.text: They represent the speaker's favorite animal

options.label: D
options.text: They represent the speaker's favorite food

multiple-choice.question: What is the overall theme of the poem "Accents"?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of speaking only one language

options.label: B
options.text: The beauty of cultural heritage and identity

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Why is this painting so shocking? - Iseult Gillespie

multiple-choice.question: What event in 1937 inspired Pablo Picasso to create his anti-war mural "Guernica"?

options.label: A
options.text: The bombing of a village in Southern Spain

options.label: B
options.text: The bombing of the Basque village of Guernica in Northern Spain

options.label: C
options.text: The start of the Spanish Civil War

options.label: D
options.text: The end of the Spanish Civil War

multiple-choice.question: What art style did Picasso pioneer and use in "Guernica"?
What effect does the Cubist style have on the viewer's perception of the objects in "Guernica"?

options.label: A
options.text: It creates a sense of depth and distance

options.label: B
options.text: It emphasizes the three-dimensionality of the objects

options.label: C
options.text: It affords viewers multiple and often impossible perspectives on the same object

options.label: D
options.text: It creates a sense of calm and serenity

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the woman holding her dead child on the far left of the painting?

options.label: A
options.text: She represents the victor in the Spanish Civil War

options.label: B
options.text: She is a symbol of hope and peace

options.label: C
options.text: She is a powerful representation of the horror and tragedy of war

options.label: D
options.text: She is a minor figure in the painting

multiple-choice.question: What is the meaning of the broken statue of a soldier in the painting?

options.label: A
options.text: He represents the strength and power of the fascist forces

options.label: B
options.text: He is a symbol of the defeat and inability to defend the innocent

options.label: C
options.text: He is a minor figure in the painting

options.label: D
options.text: He represents the end of the Spanish Civil War

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of the massive size of the canvas on the viewer's experience of the painting?

options.label: A
options.text: It creates a sense of intimacy and closeness

options.label: B
options.text: It counteracts the feeling of claustrophobia

options.label: C
options.text: It highlights the nearly life-sized atrocities on display

options.label: D
options.text: It creates a sense of distance and detachment

multiple-choice.question: What is the possible meaning of the lamp held by the ghostly woman in the painting?

options.label: A
options.text: It represents the hope and light in the midst of chaos

options.label: B
options.text: It is a symbol of the technologies of modern warfare

options.label: C
options.text: It is a minor element in the painting

options.label: D
options.text: It represents the end of the Spanish Civil War

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the animals in the painting, such as the screaming horse and the white bull?

options.label: A
options.text: They represent the brutality and chaos of war

options.label: B
options.text: They are symbols of hope and peace

options.label: C
options.text: They are minor elements in the painting

options.label: D
options.text: They represent the strength and power of the fascist forces

multiple-choice.question: What is the possible meaning of the bird at the top of the canvas?

options.label: A
options.text: It represents the hope and freedom in the midst of chaos

options.label: B
options.text: It is a symbol of the technologies of modern warfare

options.label: C
options.text: It is a minor element in the painting

options.label: D
options.text: It represents the end of the Spanish Civil War

multiple-choice.question: What is the lasting impact of "Guernica" as a work of art?

options.label: A
options.text: It has lost its power to shock and ignite debate over time

options.label: B
options.text: It is a minor work in Picasso's oeuvre

options.label: C
options.text: It remains a searing reminder of the true casualties of violence and is often referenced at anti-war gatherings

options.label: D
options.text: It is a symbol of the strength and power of the fascist forces

title: Why don’t woodpeckers get concussions?

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason woodpeckers do not get concussions when pecking into trees?

options.label: A
options.text: Their skulls are made of a harder material than humans.

options.label: B
options.text: They have a special eyelid that closes before impact.

options.label: C
options.text: The mathematics of scale mean that their brains can take a bigger banging due to their small size.

options.label: D
options.text: They have a special type of brain tissue that is resistant to damage.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the brain disease caused by repeated impacts that can lead to long-term damage?
What is the function of the hyoid bone in a woodpecker's tongue?

options.label: B
options.text: To absorb shock when the bird's head decelerates

options.label: C
options.text: To move the tongue in and out of the beak

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the main factor that determines the severity of an impact injury?

options.label: B
options.text: The area over which the force is applied

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the scientist who wrote the essay "On Being the Right Size"?
According to the transcript, what is the maximum number of G's that a human brain can withstand before concussion?
What is the main reason why woodpeckers can withstand more than 4000 G's?

options.label: A
options.text: Their brains are made of a special material

options.label: B
options.text: They have a special type of skull

options.label: C
options.text: The mathematics of scale mean that their brains can take a bigger banging due to their small size

options.label: D
options.text: They have a special type of neck muscle

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what happens to the brain when it experiences a rapid deceleration?

options.label: C
options.text: It hits the inside of the skull and damages neurons and other cells

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the type of bird that can drill thousands of holes in a single tree and hammer a seed into each one?
According to the transcript, what is the main problem with trying to prevent concussions in humans?

options.label: A
options.text: We don't have the right technology

options.label: B
options.text: We don't understand the causes of concussions

options.label: C
options.text: We are stuck with a hard knock truth: we evolved to take an impact, but not in the same way that woodpeckers did

options.label: D
options.text: We are not trying hard enough

title: We don't "move on" from grief. We move forward with it - Nora McInerny

multiple-choice.question: What significant events occurred in the speaker's life in 2014?

options.label: A
options.text: She got married, had a child, and started a new job.

options.label: B
options.text: She lost her second pregnancy, her dad died of cancer, and her husband died of brain cancer.

options.label: C
options.text: She graduated from college, started a new business, and moved to a new city.

options.label: D
options.text: She published a book, started a podcast, and founded a non-profit organization.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the group the speaker started with her friend Moe?
What phrase do people often say to those who are grieving that the speaker hates?
Why does the speaker say she hasn't "moved on" from her late husband Aaron?

options.label: A
options.text: Because she's still grieving and can't let go.

options.label: B
options.text: Because she's remarried and has a new life.

options.label: C
options.text: Because Aaron's life and death are still present for her.

options.label: D
options.text: Because she's angry and bitter about his passing.

multiple-choice.question: How does the speaker describe her experience of falling in love with her current husband Matthew?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a replacement for her love for Aaron.

options.label: B
options.text: It was a distraction from her grief.

options.label: C
options.text: It helped her realize the enormity of what she lost when Aaron died.

options.label: D
options.text: It made her forget about Aaron.

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker say about her love for Aaron and her grief for him in relation to her love for Matthew?

options.label: B
options.text: They are separate and distinct emotions.

options.label: C
options.text: They are strands of the same thread.

options.label: D
options.text: They are irrelevant to her current life.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's job, and how does it relate to her experiences with grief and loss?

options.label: A
options.text: She's a therapist who helps people cope with grief.

options.label: B
options.text: She's a writer who writes about her own experiences with loss.

options.label: C
options.text: She's a podcaster who talks to people about their worst experiences.

options.label: D
options.text: She's a non-profit founder who supports grieving widows.

multiple-choice.question: How does the speaker describe the experience of grief in relation to other life experiences?

options.label: A
options.text: It's a moment in time that will pass.

options.label: B
options.text: It's a bone that will reset.

options.label: C
options.text: It's a chronic and incurable condition.

options.label: D
options.text: It's a choice that people make.

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker say people can do to support each other in their grief?

options.label: A
options.text: Try to fix the problem and make the pain go away.

options.label: B
options.text: Remind each other that some things can't be fixed and not all wounds are meant to heal.

options.label: C
options.text: Tell each other to "move on" and get over it.

options.label: D
options.text: Avoid talking about the person who died.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message about grief and moving forward?

options.label: A
options.text: People should try to move on and forget about their loss.

options.label: B
options.text: People will never be able to move forward after a significant loss.

options.label: C
options.text: People can move forward while still carrying their grief with them.

options.label: D
options.text: People should stay stuck in their grief and never try to heal.

options.label: D
options.text: Eggs pair up in a specific order

title: You aren't at the mercy of your emotions - Lisa Feldman

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the primary factor that jurors consider when deciding between life in prison and the death penalty?

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: What is the story behind the illustration in "The Luttrell Psalter" of a young woman having her hair done and a young man catching a bird in a net?

options.label: A
options.text: It tells the story of a family scandal where a young cleric ran away with Sir Geoffrey Luttrell's daughter Elizabeth

options.label: B
options.text: It represents the devil stealing the fruits of faith

options.label: D
options.text: It represents the power of faith

multiple-choice.question: Who commissioned Christine de Pisan's collected works?

options.label: A

options.label: B

title: Turbulence: one of the great unsolved mysteries of physics - Tomás Chor

multiple-choice.question: What phenomenon is described as one of the prevailing mysteries of physics?
Which of the following systems does NOT involve moving fluids and turbulence?
What type of motion is characterized as stable and smooth in liquids and gases?
What is the term for the process by which turbulent flows break up into smaller and smaller whirls, eventually transforming into heat?
What are the two opposing forces present in every flowing liquid or gas that contribute to turbulence?
What is the Reynolds number a measure of in a flowing liquid or gas?

options.label: A
options.text: The ratio of viscosity to inertia

options.label: B
options.text: The ratio of inertia to viscosity

options.label: C
options.text: The ratio of gravity to friction

options.label: D
options.text: The ratio of pressure to temperature

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following substances is more prone to inertia and the development of turbulence?
Why is the Reynolds number ineffective in many situations, such as modeling the motion of the atmosphere?

options.label: A
options.text: It only accounts for viscosity and inertia

options.label: B
options.text: It only accounts for gravity and friction

options.label: C
options.text: It is only applicable to simple scenarios

options.label: D
options.text: It is only applicable to laminar flows

multiple-choice.question: What do most scientists think will be necessary to develop a theory that can predict turbulent flows across different situations?

options.label: C
options.text: A better understanding of gravity and friction

options.label: D
options.text: A better understanding of viscosity and inertia

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential benefit of developing a true understanding of turbulence?

options.label: B
options.text: Better preparation for catastrophic weather events

title: The wild world of carnivorous plants - Kenny Coogan

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the death of the six creatures mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: They are all killed by other animals.

options.label: B
options.text: They are all killed by a carnivorous plant.

options.label: C
options.text: They are all killed by a natural disaster.

options.label: D
options.text: They are all killed by a human.

multiple-choice.question: Approximately how many plant species around the world supplement their diet with insects, microbes, or small animals?
What is believed to be the reason for the evolution of carnivory in plants?

options.label: C
options.text: To obtain crucial nutrients like nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium

multiple-choice.question: In what type of soil do carnivorous plants tend to grow?

options.label: D
options.text: Soil with high levels of nutrients

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the coniine in the pitcher plant's nectar?

options.label: C
options.text: To act as a powerful narcotic to insects

options.label: D
options.text: To provide nutrients to the plant

multiple-choice.question: How does the sundew plant trap its prey?

options.label: A
options.text: With a sticky secretion called mucilage

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the bladderwort plant?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the slowest of all carnivorous plants

options.label: B
options.text: It is the speediest of all carnivorous plants

options.label: C
options.text: It is the largest of all carnivorous plants

options.label: D
options.text: It is the smallest of all carnivorous plants

multiple-choice.question: How does the Venus flytrap plant trap its prey?

options.label: C
options.text: With tiny hairs that trigger the jaws to snap shut

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the long flower stalks on the butterwort plant?

options.label: A
options.text: To attract more insects to the plant's traps

options.label: C
options.text: To provide nutrients to the plant

options.label: D
options.text: To protect the plant from herbivores

multiple-choice.question: Which insect is able to escape the carnivorous plants and live a long and fruitful life?

title: How to biohack your cells to fight cancer - Greg Foot

multiple-choice.question: What is the main function of the human body's cells in terms of evolution?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a perfect copy of the genetic code

options.label: B
options.text: To safeguard the genetic code, duplicate it, and pass it on

options.label: C
options.text: To fight off pathogens and diseases

options.label: D
options.text: To grow and multiply into tumors

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the process of cells making mistakes in copying their genetic code, leading to changes in the code?
What type of scientists are working on rewriting the genetic code to fix un-fixable diseases?
What is the name of the therapy that involves reprogramming a patient's immune system to recognize and destroy cancer cells?
What are the two types of white blood cells that play a crucial role in the immune system?
What is the main challenge in treating cancer with traditional methods?

options.label: A
options.text: The cancer cells are too aggressive

options.label: B
options.text: The cancer cells are too widespread

options.label: C
options.text: The immune system has trouble recognizing cancer cells

options.label: D
options.text: The cancer cells are too resistant to treatment

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the new genetic code designed for T-cells in CAR T-cell therapy?

options.label: A
options.text: To recognize and kill cancer cells

options.label: B
options.text: To make copies of itself when it finds cancer cells

options.label: C
options.text: To survive in the patient's body

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the mythological creature that inspired the name "CAR T-cell"?
What is the advantage of CAR T-cells over traditional chemical-based drugs?

options.label: B
options.text: They are more effective against solid cancers

options.label: C
options.text: They stay in the patient's bloodstream for years

multiple-choice.question: What has been the result of CAR T-cell therapy on the survival rate for B acute lymphoblastic leukemia?

options.label: B
options.text: The survival rate has remained the same

options.label: C
options.text: The survival rate has improved slightly

options.label: D
options.text: The survival rate has improved hugely

title: How childhood trauma affects health across a lifetime - Nadine Burke Harris

multiple-choice.question: What did the CDC and Kaiser Permanente discover in the mid-'90s that dramatically increased the risk for seven out of 10 of the leading causes of death in the United States?
According to the speaker, what is the effect of high doses of childhood trauma on brain development, the immune system, and hormonal systems?

options.label: C
options.text: It affects brain development, the immune system, and hormonal systems

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the study that changed the speaker's clinical practice and ultimately their career?
What is the term used to describe the experiences that are included in the Adverse Childhood Experiences Study?
According to the speaker, what is the relationship between ACEs and health outcomes?

options.label: B
options.text: The higher your ACE score, the better your health outcomes

options.label: C
options.text: The higher your ACE score, the worse your health outcomes

options.label: D
options.text: The lower your ACE score, the worse your health outcomes

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the center that the speaker created to prevent, screen, and heal the impacts of ACEs and toxic stress?
According to the speaker, what is the most important thing that we need today to address the issue of ACEs and toxic stress?

options.label: C
options.text: The courage to look this problem in the face and say, this is real and this is all of us

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the brain's and body's stress response system that governs our fight-or-flight response?
According to the speaker, what is the effect of repeated stress activation on children's brains and bodies?

options.label: C
options.text: It affects brain structure and function, the developing immune system, developing hormonal systems, and even the way our DNA is read and transcribed

options.label: D
options.text: It only affects brain structure and function

multiple-choice.question: Who is quoted as saying, "Adverse childhood experiences are the single greatest unaddressed public health threat facing our nation today"?

title: How to spot a pyramid scheme - Stacie Bosley

multiple-choice.question: What was the initial investment required to join Vemma Nutrition in 2004?
How many new members was Vemma Nutrition bringing in per month at its peak?
What is the primary difference between a pyramid scheme and a Ponzi scheme?

options.label: A
options.text: Pyramid schemes are more common than Ponzi schemes

options.label: B
options.text: Pyramid schemes involve recruiting new members to buy in, while Ponzi schemes use fees to pay existing members

options.label: C
options.text: Pyramid schemes are more profitable than Ponzi schemes

options.label: D
options.text: Pyramid schemes are easier to detect than Ponzi schemes

multiple-choice.question: Why do pyramid schemes become increasingly difficult for new recruits to make money?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of participants decreases over time

options.label: B
options.text: The number of participants remains constant

options.label: C
options.text: The number of participants expands exponentially

options.label: D
options.text: The number of participants grows linearly

multiple-choice.question: What is the key distinction between pyramid schemes and legitimate multi-level marketing companies?

options.label: A
options.text: Pyramid schemes require a higher initial investment

options.label: B
options.text: Pyramid schemes primarily compensate members for recruitment, while multi-level marketing companies primarily compensate members for sales

options.label: C
options.text: Pyramid schemes are more profitable than multi-level marketing companies

options.label: D
options.text: Pyramid schemes are more common than multi-level marketing companies

multiple-choice.question: How do many pyramid schemes disguise themselves?
What is a common tactic used by pyramid schemes to capitalize on existing trust?

options.label: C
options.text: Encouraging the first few members to report a good experience before they actually start making a profit

multiple-choice.question: Why do many victims of pyramid schemes remain silent?

options.label: C
options.text: They are unaware of the scheme's true nature

options.label: D
options.text: They are ashamed of their financial situation

multiple-choice.question: What is a red flag that may indicate a pyramid scheme?

options.label: A
options.text: A promise of a steady, low-risk income

options.label: B
options.text: A requirement to pay for the opportunity to sell a product or service

options.label: C
options.text: Time pressure to "act now or miss a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity"

options.label: D
options.text: A guarantee of a full refund if the business fails

multiple-choice.question: What is a key characteristic of a legitimate multi-level marketing business?

options.label: A
options.text: Requiring members to pay for the opportunity to sell a product or service

options.label: D
options.text: Not requiring members to pay for the opportunity to sell a product or service

title: Why do we laugh?

options.text: It is an unconscious, instantaneous reaction

options.label: D
options.text: It is a form of verbal communication

title: What “Machiavellian” really means - Pazit Cahlon and Alex Gendler

options.text: As a guide for moral leadership

options.text: As a manual for tyrannical rulers

options.text: As a critique of individual rights

options.label: C
